{{Politics of the Czech Republic}}
'''Czech law''', often referred to as the '''legal order of the Czech Republic''' (''{{lang|cs|pr√°vn√≠ ≈ô√°d ƒåesk√© republiky}}''), is the [[Law|system of legal rules]] in force in the [[Czech Republic]], and in the international community it is a member of. Czech [[List of national legal systems|legal system]] belongs to the Germanic branch of continental legal culture ([[Civil law (legal system)|civil law]]).<ref name="bobek">Bobek, Michal. [http://www.nyulawglobal.org/Globalex/Czech_Republic1.htm "UPDATE: An Introduction to the Czech Legal System and Legal Resources Online. "] ''GlobaLex''. Hauser Global Law School Program, New York University School of Law, Sept. 2009. Web. 07 Dec. 2012.</ref> Major areas of [[Public law|public]] and [[private law]] are divided into branches, among them civil, criminal, administrative, procedural and labour law, and systematically codified.
Written law is the basis of the legal order, and the most important [[Sources of law|source of law]] are: [[Regulation|legal regulations]] ([[Act of Parliament|acts of parliament]], as well as [[delegated legislation]]), [[Treaty|international treaties]] (once they have been [[Ratification|ratified]] by the parliament and [[Promulgation|promulgated]]), and such findings of the [[Constitutional Court of the Czech Republic]], in which a statute or its part has been nullified as [[Constitutionality|unconstitutional]]. It is [[government gazette|made public]] by the periodically published ''{{lang|cs|Sb√≠rka z√°kon≈Ø}}'', abbreviated ''Sb.'' (‚ÄúCollection of Law‚Äù, ‚ÄúColl.‚Äù), and ''{{lang|cs|Sb√≠rka mezin√°rodn√≠ch smluv}}'', abbreviated ''Sb. m. s.'' (‚ÄúCollection of International Treaties‚Äù).
The system of law and justice in the Czech Republic has been in constant development since the [[Velvet Revolution|1989 regime change]]. In 1993, the [[Constitution of the Czech Republic]] has been enacted, which postulates the [[Rechtsstaat|rule of law]], outlines the [[Politics of the Czech Republic|structure and principles of democratic government]], and declares human rights and rights of the citizen. Since 2004, the membership in the EU means the priority of [[European Union law]] over Czech law in some areas. Recently, a brand new Criminal Code entered into force in 2010, and the Civil Code followed in 2014.
== Sources of law ==
Sources of Czech law are (in this hierarchical order):<ref name="bobek" />
* the Constitution (''{{lang|cs|√östava}}'') and constitutional acts (''{{lang|cs|√∫stavn√≠ z√°kony}}'') * international treaties ratified by the Parliament (''{{lang|cs|mezin√°rodn√≠ smlouvy ratifikovan√© parlamentem}}'') * statutes adopted by the Parliament (''{{lang|cs|z√°kony p≈ôijat√© parlamentem}}''), published decisions of the [[Constitutional Court of the Czech Republic|Constitutional Court]] * derived legislation: government orders<ref>also translated as government decrees</ref> (''{{lang|cs|na≈ô√≠zen√≠ vl√°dy}}'') and notifications of ministries<ref>sometimes orders of ministries</ref> (''{{lang|cs|vyhl√°≈°ky ministerstev}}''); legislative acts of territorial self-government bodies: regional ordinances<ref>or [[by-law|byelaws]], if you prefer</ref> (''{{lang|cs|krajsk√© vyhl√°≈°ky}}'') and municipal ordinances (''{{lang|cs|obecn√≠ vyhl√°≈°ky}}'')
Acts of parliament and other legal regulations enter into force on the day they are [[Promulgation|promulgated]] (published) in the official ''Collection of Law'' (''{{lang|cs|Sb√≠rka z√°kon≈Ø}}'', abbreviated as ''{{lang|cs|Sb.}}'' ‚Äì ''Coll.'' ‚Äì when referring to statutes), although they may take effect at a later date. International treaties are similarly published in the ''Collection of International Treaties'' (''{{lang|cs|Sb√≠rka mezin√°rodn√≠ch smluv}}'', abbreviated ''Sb. m. s.'').<ref>[http://aplikace.mvcr.cz/sbirka-zakonu/ Official online version of Collection of Law and Collection of International Treaties]</ref>
[[File:Sb√≠rka z√°kon≈Ø 1993 ƒç√°stka 001 strana 01.png|thumb|The Constitution of the Czech Republic as published in the Collection of Laws]]
=== Constitutional law ===
Czech [[constitution]] is written, and it consists of several [[Constitutional act of the Czech Republic|constitutional acts]] (one of them [[Constitution of the Czech Republic|the Constitution of the Czech Republic]]), together they are known as the [[constitutional order of the Czech Republic]] (''{{lang|cs|√∫stavn√≠ po≈ô√°dek}}'').
The constitution can be viewed as [[Entrenched clause|entrenched]], because constitutional statutes are more difficult to adopt, amend, supplement or repeal them than ordinary laws of the country. A special majority (constitutional supermajority) is required of three-fifths of all Deputies and a qualified majority of three-fifths of all Senators present.<ref name="bobek" /><ref name="concourt1">Czech Republic. Constitutional Court. [http://www.concourt.cz/clanek/2092 "Constitutional Order of the Czech Republic. "] ''The Constitutional Court of the Czech Republic. '' √östavn√≠ soud ƒåR, n.d. Web. 03 Jan. 2013.</ref> This is to promote continuity and stability of the political system.
Most important constitutional acts are:
* Constitutional Act No. 1/1993 Coll. the Constitution of the Czech Republic<ref group=cs>[http://portal.gov.cz/app/zakony/zakonPar.jsp?idBiblio=40450&fulltext=&nr=&part=&name=1~2F1993&rpp=15#local-content √östavn√≠ z√°kon ƒç. 1/1993 Sb. √östava ƒåesk√© republiky]</ref> * Resolution No. 2/1993 Coll. [...] incorporating Charter of Fundamental Rights and Basic Freedoms [...]<ref group=cs>[http://portal.gov.cz/app/zakony/zakonPar.jsp?idBiblio=40453&fulltext=&nr=&part=&name=2~2F1993&rpp=15#local-content Usnesen√≠ ƒç. 2/1993 Sb. P≈ôedsednictva ƒåesk√© n√°rodn√≠ rady o vyhl√°≈°en√≠ LISTINY Z√ÅKLADN√çCH PR√ÅV A SVOBOD jako souƒç√°sti √∫stavn√≠ho po≈ô√°dku ƒåesk√© republiky]</ref><ref>In full: Resolution no. 2/1993 Coll. of the Presidium of the Czech National Council of 16 December 1992 on the declaration of the Charter of Fundamental Rights and Basic Freedoms as a part of the constitutional order of the Czech Republic</ref> * Constitutional Act No. 110/1998 Coll. on the Security of the Czech Republic<ref group=cs>[http://portal.gov.cz/app/zakony/zakonPar.jsp?idBiblio=46612&fulltext=&nr=&part=&name=110~2F1998&rpp=15#local-content √östavn√≠ z√°kon ƒç. 110/1998 Sb. o bezpeƒçnosti ƒåesk√© republiky]</ref> * Constitutional Act No. 347/1997 Coll. on the Creation of Higher Territorial Self-Governing Units<ref group=cs>[http://portal.gov.cz/app/zakony/zakonPar.jsp?idBiblio=45807&fulltext=&nr=&part=&name=347~2F1997&rpp=15#local-content Z√°kon ƒç. 347/1997 Sb. o vytvo≈ôen√≠ vy≈°≈°√≠ch √∫zemn√≠ch samospr√°vn√Ωch celk≈Ø a o zmƒõnƒõ √∫stavn√≠ho z√°kona ƒåesk√© n√°rodn√≠ rady ƒç. 1/1993 Sb., √östava ƒåesk√© republiky]</ref>
The 1992 [[Constitution of the Czech Republic]] declares sovereignty (self-government) of the people and the values of freedom and democracy. It defines the separation of the three powers in a system of [[Separation of powers|Checks and balances]]. It gives the legislative power to the popularly elected [[Parliament of the Czech Republic|Czech Parliament]] consisting of two chambers, the [[Chamber of Deputies of the Parliament of the Czech Republic|Chamber of Deputies]] and the [[Senate of the Parliament of the Czech Republic|Senate]]. The executive power is divided between the [[President of the Czech Republic|President]] and the [[List of Prime Ministers of the Czech Republic|Prime Minister]]. It describes the functioning of the [[Judiciary of the Czech Republic|judiciary]], especially the [[Constitutional Court of the Czech Republic|Constitutional Court]]. Two more institutions are established, the [[Czech National Bank]] and the [[Supreme Audit Office of the Czech Republic|Supreme Audit Office]].
The [[Charter of Fundamental Rights and Basic Freedoms]] (''{{lang|cs|Listina z√°kladn√≠ch pr√°v a svobod}}'') is a [[bill of rights]] document enacted in 1991 by the [[Czech and Slovak Federative Republic|Czechoslovak Federative Republic]]. In the Czech Republic it was kept in its entirety and forms a part of the constitutional order (i.e. has the same legal force as the Constitution). It postulates the sanctity of natural human rights and fundamental freedoms as well as citizens' (political) rights, the equality before the law, rights of minorities and so on.
The Constitution has been seriously modified in February 2012, introducing a controversial popular vote of the [[President of the Czech Republic]]:<ref name="concourt1" />
* Constitutional Act No. 71/2012 Coll.<ref group=cs>[http://portal.gov.cz/app/zakony/zakonPar.jsp?idBiblio=77110&fulltext=&nr=&part=&name=71~2F2012&rpp=15#local-content √östavn√≠ z√°kon ƒç. 71/2012 Sb., kter√Ωm se mƒõn√≠ √∫stavn√≠ z√°kon ƒç. 1/1993 Sb., √östava ƒåesk√© republiky, ve znƒõn√≠ pozdƒõj≈°√≠ch √∫stavn√≠ch z√°kon≈Ø]</ref><ref>which amends the Constitutional Act No. 1/1993 Coll., the Constitution of the Czech Republic as amended by subsequent constitutional acts</ref>
=== International treaties ===
On joining the [[European Union]], the Czech Republic committed itself to respect the principle of the supremacy of [[Community acquis|European law]] over Czech law in defined areas.<ref>Czech Republic. Ministry of Foreign Affairs. "[http://www.czech.cz/en/Life-Work/How-things-work-here/Law/The-system-of-independent-courts The System of Independent Courts]. " ''[http://www.czech.cz Hello Czech Republic (Czech Republic - The Official Website)]''. Ministry of Foreign Affairs, 01 Jan. 2010. Web. 07 Dec. 2012.</ref>
The most important treaty in this category is the [[Council of Europe]]‚Äôs [[European Convention on Human Rights|Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms]].<ref name="bobek" />
=== Statutes adopted by the Parliament ===
Major areas of Czech law are codified in a systematic manner.
==== Criminal law ====
Most important statutes in the criminal justice field are:
* Act No. 40/2009 Coll., the Criminal Code<ref group=cs>[http://portal.gov.cz/app/zakony/zakonPar.jsp?idBiblio=68040&fulltext=&nr=&part=&name=40~2F2009&rpp=50#local-content Z√°kon ƒç. 40/2009 Sb trestn√≠ z√°kon√≠k]</ref> * Act No. 141/1961 Coll., the Criminal Procedure Code<ref group=cs>[http://portal.gov.cz/app/zakony/zakonPar.jsp?idBiblio=30139&fulltext=&nr=&part=&name=141~2F1961&rpp=50#local-content Z√°kon ƒç. 141/1961 Sb. o trestn√≠m ≈ô√≠zen√≠ soudn√≠m (trestn√≠ ≈ô√°d)]</ref><ref>sometimes rendered as Code of Criminal Justice</ref> * Act No. 218/2003 Coll., on Juvenile Criminal Justice<ref group=cs>[http://portal.gov.cz/app/zakony/zakonPar.jsp?idBiblio=55745&fulltext=&nr=&part=&name=218~2F2003&rpp=50#local-content Z√°kon ƒç. 218/2003 Sb. o odpovƒõdnosti ml√°de≈æe za protipr√°vn√≠ ƒçiny a o soudnictv√≠ ve vƒõcech ml√°de≈æe a o zmƒõnƒõ nƒõkter√Ωch z√°kon≈Ø (z√°kon o soudnictv√≠ ve vƒõcech ml√°de≈æe)]</ref>
Since 2010, Czech [[criminal law]] is regulated mainly, though not only, by the Criminal Code Act 2009 (''{{lang|cs|trestn√≠ z√°kon√≠k}}''), which codifies substantive criminal law. The comprehensive regulatory statute for criminal procedure is the Criminal Proceedings Code Act 1961 (''{{lang|cs|trestn√≠ ≈ô√°d}}''). The two codes are complemented by the Juvenile Criminal Justice Act 2003, which deals with alleged offenders aged between 15 (the threshold of criminal liability as well as [[Age of consent|age of legal consent]]) and 17.
Until 2009, the criminal code statute in force dated back to 1961. In spite of numerous amendments made since the 1989, it still conformed to the communist ideology, oriented on punishment of perceived enemies of the socialist regime. As a part of an effort to comprehensively reform law and justice, a brand new codification has been written. The Ministry of Justice announced it as an "elaborate piece of work boiled down from the experience and knowledge of foremost expert on criminal law", which can be proudly compared to modern criminal codes of other democratic countries.<ref name="moj">Czech Republic. Ministerstvo spravedlnosti ƒåR. [http://reforma.justice.cz/cz/trestni-zakonik/obecne-o-trestnim-zakoniku.html "Obecnƒõ o trestn√≠m z√°kon√≠ku. "] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20130217044737/http://reforma.justice.cz/cz/trestni-zakonik/obecne-o-trestnim-zakoniku.html |date=2013-02-17 }} ''Reforma justice. '' Ministerstvo spravedlnosti ƒåR, n.d. Web. 12 Dec. 2012.</ref>
The purpose of the 2009 codification was to bring the criminal justice system in line with the rest of Europe. The main change introduced by the code was transition from material to formal conception of criminal offence. Another thing the lawyers drafting the 2009 code had in mind, and expressed it in the area of sentencing tariffs, was a new balance of punishment against rehabilitation effect on the criminal. On one hand we see the sentences for felony (''{{lang|cs|zloƒçin}}'') which carry a sentence of at least 5 years. On the other a newly created category of misdemeanour (''{{lang|cs|p≈ôeƒçin}}'') introduces a host of community sentences (''{{lang|cs|alternativn√≠ tresty}}''), including community payback (''{{lang|cs|ve≈ôejnƒõ prospƒõ≈°n√© pr√°ce}}'') or house arrest (''{{lang|cs|dom√°c√≠ vƒõzen√≠}}''). The code also outlaws doping.<ref name="moj" />
Less serious breaches of law are called [[contravention]]s (''{{lang|cs|p≈ôestupek}}'').<ref>The word ''p≈ôestupek'' (pl. ''p≈ôestupky'') can be found translated variously, even in official translations, as ''infraction'', ''administrative infraction'', ''administrative offence'', ''offence'' (!), ''offence'', ''transgression'', ''misdemeanour'', or ''violation''.</ref> These are not normally dealt with by the courts of law, but rather punished either by the police on the spot, or through a procedure in front of a committee at the local or municipal authority, or sometimes other administration body. The result is not a conviction, and so such a punishment will not blemish the culprit's criminal record. Like with other administrative acts, the outcome of this procedure can be challenged through the administrative justice process.<ref>{{cite book|last=Novotn√Ω|first=V√°clav|title=Administrative Justice in Europe ‚Äì Report for the Czech Republic|date=n.d.|publisher=Association of Councils of State and Supreme Administrative Jurisdictions|url=http://www.juradmin.eu/en/eurtour/i/countries/czech/czech_en.pdf}}</ref> A typical example of contraventions in Czech law this are driving offences. (In the common law world, acts falling into this category would be classed as [[summary offence]]s.) * Act No. 200/1990 on Contraventions<ref group=cs>[http://portal.gov.cz/app/zakony/zakonPar.jsp?idBiblio=38544&fulltext=&nr=&part=&name=p~C5~99estupky&rpp=50#local-content Z√°kon ƒç. 200/1990 Sb. o p≈ôestupc√≠ch]</ref>
Since 2012, Czech law also recognizes [[Corporate liability|criminal liability of corporations]] for offences committed by employees of a corporation, when acting on its behalf, being instructed by the board of directors or other representative of the company, or through lack of their action. In such cases, not only individuals will be prosecuted, but the corporation can be prosecuted as well for the same offence and punished by a host of measures, starting from cetrain injunctions, through fines a forfeitures, to liquidation of the company.<ref>{{cite news|last=Trubaƒç|first=Onde≈ôej|title=Trestn√≠ odpovƒõdnost pr√°vnick√© osoby|url=http://finance.idnes.cz/trestni-odpovednost-pravnickych-osob-dhf-/pravo.aspx?c=A120305_210154_pravo_vr|accessdate=17 February 2013|newspaper=iDNES.cz|date=5 March 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Skalick√°|first=Hana|title=Corporate Criminal Liability in the Czech Republic|url=http://www.terralex.org/publication/p58cf9663e3/corporate-criminal-liability-in-the-czech-republic|work=Newsletter - TerraLex Practice Groups|publisher=TerraLex|accessdate=17 February 2013|date=22 June 2012}}</ref>
* Act No. 418/2011 Coll., on Criminal Liability of Legal Persons and the Proceedings against Them<ref group=cs>[http://portal.gov.cz/app/zakony/zakonPar.jsp?idBiblio=75794&fulltext=&nr=418~2F2011&part=&name=&rpp=50#local-content Z√°kon ƒç. 418/2011 Sb. o trestn√≠ odpovƒõdnosti pr√°vnick√Ωch osob a ≈ô√≠zen√≠ proti nim]</ref>
==== Civil law ====
Main statutes regulating this area are:
* Act No. 89/2012 Coll. the Civil Code<ref group=cs>[http://www.psp.cz/sqw/sbirka.sqw?r=2012&cz=89 Z√°kon ƒç. 89/2012 Sb. obƒçansk√Ω z√°kon√≠k]</ref> * Act No. 99/1963 Coll. the Civil Procedure Code<ref group=cs>[http://portal.gov.cz/app/zakony/zakonPar.jsp?idBiblio=30398&src=dulezite&rpp=50#local-content Z√°kon ƒç. 99/1963 Sb. obƒçansk√Ω soudn√≠ ≈ô√°d]</ref><ref>sometimes rendered Code of Civil Justice</ref> * Act No. 500/2004 Coll. the Administrative Procedure Code<ref group=cs>[http://portal.gov.cz/app/zakony/zakonPar.jsp?idBiblio=58370&fulltext=&nr=500~2F2004&part=&name=&rpp=50#local-content Z√°kon ƒç. 500/2004 Sb. spr√°vn√≠ ≈ô√°d]</ref><ref>also Code of Administrative Procedure</ref>
The Civil Code codifies core areas of [[private law]]. It has five parts. The first part is dedicated to a legal status of a person as an individual. The second regulates family law ‚Äì e.g. the institute of marriage and the rights and obligations of husband and wife, parents and children.<ref name="novyoz" /> Although the Code does include [[Recognition of same-sex unions in the Czech Republic|registered partnership]], it explicitly prohibits adoption to a person in a registered partnership.<ref>[http://obcanskyzakonik.justice.cz/tinymce-storage/files/sb0033-2012.pdf "Z√°kon 89/2012 obƒçansk√Ω z√°kon√≠k. "] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120709040352/http://obcanskyzakonik.justice.cz/tinymce-storage/files/sb0033-2012.pdf |date=2012-07-09 }} ''Sb√≠rka z√°kon≈Ø. '' 03 Feb 2009.</ref> The rest in concerned mainly with property rights.<ref name="novyoz" />
The civil code regulation effective since 1 January 2014 is a result of eleven years of work of the recodification committee of the [[Ministry of Justice (Czech Republic)|Ministry of Justice]]. Together with the Commercial Corporations Act and the Private International Law Act it constitutes a complete recodification of private law in the Czech Republic.<ref name="novyoz">Czech Republic. Ministerstvo spravedlnosti ƒåR. [http://obcanskyzakonik.justice.cz/cz/uvodni-stranka.html "√övodn√≠ str√°nka. "] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121105141004/http://obcanskyzakonik.justice.cz/cz/uvodni-stranka.html |date=2012-11-05 }} ''Nov√Ω obƒçansk√Ω z√°kon√≠k. '' Ministerstvo spravedlnosti ƒåR, n.d. Web. 12 Dec. 2012.</ref> It brings new and modern regulation of relations governed by civil law, with emphasis on personality rights, free will / more choice when writing a will or unified regulation of obligation laws.<ref name="novyoz" />
=== Case law ===
Theoretically, case law is not defined as a source of law in the Czech Republic. Despite that, the decisions of courts, namely supreme courts and the Constitutional Court, have a significant influence over the Czech legal system since 1989.<ref name="bobek" /> Findings of the Constitutional Court are considered a source of law, and are binding for general courts.<ref>"Enforceable rulings of the Constitutional Court shall be binding for all agencies and individuals. " ‚Äì Constitution, Art. 89</ref> If a lower court is to rule against "consistent adjudications" of the Supreme Court on the point of law, it must give detailed reasoning, and this can often be a reason for a successful appeal. This system is largely based on judiciary's own interpretation of the Constitution, arguing that it gives citizens predictability and fairness.<ref>{{cite news|last=Fetter|first=Richard W.|title=Musej√≠ ni≈æ≈°√≠ soudy poslouchat Nejvy≈°≈°√≠ soud?|url=http://www.ceskenoviny.cz/paragrafy/zpravy/museji-nizsi-soudy-poslouchat-nejvyssi-soud/453253|accessdate=7 January 2013|newspaper=ƒåesk√© noviny|date=24 March 2010}}</ref> The most significant judgements of both courts are published in the official Collection of Laws.<ref name="concourt2">Czech Republic. Constitutional Court. [http://www.concourt.cz/clanek/2094 "Introduction. "] ''The Constitutional Court of the Czech Republic. '' √östavn√≠ soud ƒåR, n.d. Web. 03 Jan. 2013.</ref>
== History == [[File:Theresiana-Titel.jpg|thumb|[[Constitutio Criminalis Theresiana]], 1768]] In [[Czech lands]], the process of formation of modern legislation dates back to the era of [[enlightened absolutism]], when they were a core part of the [[Austrian Empire]]. Reforms of government were to a large extent the work of empress [[Maria Theresa]] and her son [[Joseph II, Holy Roman Emperor|Joseph II]], who participated in creating the first [[civil code]] of the country in 1787, called [[Josephinisches Gesetzbuch]]. This was a forbearer to the comprehensive codification of civil law in 1811, known as the [[Allgemeines b√ºrgerliches Gesetzbuch]] (ABGB). ABGB was [[Reception statute|received]] in 1918 by Czechoslovakia, among other successor states, but only for Czech lands (Bohemia, Moravia and Austrian Silesia), while Slovakia kept the customary law of Hungary. Albeit updated many times, this Austrian law was kept in Czechoslovakia, along with the legal duality, until 1950, when the "Middle Civil Code" was promulgated, soon to be superseded by the civil code of 1964, which will be in force until the "New Civil Code", enacted in 2009, will enter in force in 2014.
Following in the tracks of their enlightenment predecessors, the [[Constitutio criminalis Josephina]] of 1707 and the [[Constitutio criminalis Theresiana]] of 1768, the most important Czechoslovakian [[criminal code]]s were enacted in 1950, 1961 and 2009.
The history of Czechoslovak constitutionality starts with the formation of independent [[Czechoslovakia]] out of the ruins of [[Austria-Hungary]]. In 1918, the [[Interim Constitution of Czechoslovakia]] has been enacted hastily, establishing the republic with its president and temporary parliament. The [[Czechoslovak Constitution of 1920]] succeeded it, inspired by western democratic constitutions, and, controversially, postulating the [[Czechoslovakism|Czechoslovak nation]]. This lasted over the [[First Czechoslovak Republic|First Republic]] and the second world war. In 1948, the so-called [[Ninth-of-May Constitution]] was enacted after the [[1948 Czechoslovak coup d'√©tat|communist coup]] ‚Äì preserving some democratic institutions (human rights, partial division of the three powers, independent judiciary), though the political reality of the country departed from it radically. The [[1960 Constitution of Czechoslovakia]], influenced by soviet constitutions, is often dubbed the "Socialist Constitution". It changed the name of the country to [[Czechoslovak Socialist Republic|Czechoslovak ''Socialist'' Republic]] and defined socialist, rather than democratic, character of the state, and introduced the leading role of the [[Communist Party of Czechoslovakia]]. The 1960 constitution remained in force until 1992, although in 1968 it was substantially modified by the [[Constitutional Act on the Czechoslovak Federation]] ‚Äì this transformed the unitary state into a federation of the [[Czech Socialist Republic]] and the [[Slovak Socialist Republic]]. Further radical modifications were enacted after the [[Velvet Revolution|regime change of 1989]], but they turned out to be short-lived, as in 1992 the [[Constitution of the Czech Republic]] has been promulgated after the [[Dissolution of Czechoslovakia|division of Czechoslovakia]], and entered into force in 1993.

{{italic title}} '''''Life of Jesus''''' ({{lang-de|Das Leben Jesu}}) is one of the earliest works by [[Georg Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel|G. W. F. Hegel]]. It remained an unpublished fragment, found amongst his posthumous papers. In this essay on morality he presents a version of [[Jesus]] very similar to [[Immanuel Kant]]'s [[categorical imperative]]; it also stays close to Kant's ''[[Religion Within the Limits of Reason Alone]]''. For Hegel the moment Jesus cried out "why hast thou forsaken me", was the moment he knew [[sin]] and evil, for evil is the separation of the individual from the universal.
Jesus is presented as a rationalistic philosopher, opposed to the superstition and "positive religion" of the [[Pharisee]]s. Positive religion is a religion that has a definite historic founder,<ref>{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Merriam-Webster definition | work = | format = | publisher = Merriam-Webster | date = | url = http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/positive%20religion | accessdate = April 21, 2012}}</ref> and is characterised rather sociologically: at this stage religion becomes an objective system of laws and rules.
Hegel presented biblical miracles as metaphors for Jesus' philosophical doctrines. Whether related with the tenor of Hegel's philosophy of [[immanence]], or just because it remained fragment, the history stops with the crucifixion. The paschal event is absent.

W. F. Hegel and the Life of Jesus: (Das Leben Jesu)'' Translated with Introduction by Michael George] 1981

A '''linear response function''' describes the input-output relationship of a [[signal transducer]] such as a radio turning [[electromagnetic wave]]s into music or a [[neuron]] turning [[Synapse|synaptic]] input into a response. Because of its many applications in [[information theory]], [[physics]] and [[engineering]] there exist alternative names for specific linear response functions such as [[Magnetic susceptibility|susceptibility]], [[impulse response]] or [[Electrical impedance|impedance]], see also [[transfer function]]. The concept of a [[Green's function]] or [[fundamental solution]] of an [[ordinary differential equation]] is closely related.
==Mathematical definition==
Denote the input of a system by <math>h(t)</math> (e.g. a [[force]]), and the response of the system by <math>x(t)</math> (e.g. a position). Generally, the value of <math>x(t)</math> will depend not only on the present value of <math>h(t)</math>, but also on past values. Approximately <math>x(t)</math> is a weighted sum of the previous values of <math>h(t')</math>, with the weights given by the linear response function <math>\chi(t-t')</math>:
:<math>x(t)=\int_{-\infty}^t dt'\, \chi(t-t')h(t')+\dots\,.</math>
The explicit term on the right-hand side is the [[leading-order|leading order]] term of a [[Volterra series|Volterra expansion]] for the full nonlinear response. If the system in question is highly non-linear, higher order terms in the expansion, denoted by the dots, become important and the signal transducer cannot adequately be described just by its linear response function.
The complex-valued [[Fourier transform]] <math>\tilde{\chi}(\omega) </math> of the linear response function is very useful as it describes the output of the system if the input is a sine wave <math>h(t)=h_0\cdot \sin(\omega t)</math> with frequency <math>\omega</math>. The output reads
:<math>x(t)=|\tilde{\chi}(\omega)|\cdot h_0 \cdot\sin(\omega t+\arg\tilde{\chi}(\omega))\,,</math>
with [[Amplifier|amplitude gain]] <math>|\tilde{\chi}(\omega)|</math> and [[phase shift]] <math>\arg\tilde{\chi}(\omega)</math>.
==Example== Consider a [[damped harmonic oscillator]] with input given by an external driving force <math>h(t)</math>,
:<math>\ddot{x}(t)+\gamma \dot{x}(t)+\omega_0^2 x(t)=h(t). \, </math>
The complex-valued [[Fourier transform]] of the linear response function is given by
:<math>\tilde{\chi}(\omega) = \frac{\tilde{x}(\omega)}{\tilde{h}(\omega)} = \frac{1}{\omega_0^2-\omega^2+i\gamma\omega}. \, </math>
The amplitude gain is given by the magnitude of the complex number <math>\tilde\chi (\omega ),</math> and the phase shift by the arctan of the imaginary part of the function, divided by the real one.
From this representation, we see that for small <math>\gamma</math> the Fourier transform <math>\tilde{\chi}(\omega) </math> of the linear response function yields a pronounced maximum ("[[Resonance]]") at the frequency <math> \omega\approx\omega_0</math>. The linear response function for a harmonic oscillator is mathematically identical to that of an [[RLC circuit]]. The width of the maximum <math>,\Delta\omega ,</math> typically is much smaller than <math>\omega_0 ,</math> so that the [[Quality factor]] <math>S :=\omega_0 /\Delta\omega</math> can be extremely large.
==Kubo formula== The exposition of linear response theory, in the context of [[quantum statistics]], can be found in a paper by [[Ryogo Kubo]].<ref>Kubo, R., ''Statistical Mechanical Theory of Irreversible Processes I'', Journal of the Physical Society of Japan, vol. ''12'', pp. 570‚Äì586 (1957).</ref> This defines particularly the [[Kubo formula]], which considers the general case that the "force" h(t) is a perturbation of the basic operator of the system, the [[Hamiltonian function|Hamiltonian]], <math>\hat H_0\to \hat{H}_0 -h(t')\hat{B}(t')\, </math> where <math>\hat B</math> corresponds to a measurable quantity as input, while the output x(t) is the perturbation of the thermal expectation of another measurable quantity <math>\hat A(t)</math>. The Kubo formula then defines the quantum-statistical calculation of the [[susceptibility (disambiguation)|susceptibility]] <math>\chi ( t -t' )</math> by a general formula involving only the mentioned operators. <!-- It is <math>\chi ( t -t' )= -(i/\hbar )\cdot \langle [\hat{A }(t-t' ),\hat B(0)]\rangle_{\text{thermal expectation}},</math> where the brackets mean the thermal expectation value, the expression [... , ...] the quantum [[commutator]], and <math>\hat{A(t-t')}</math> must be evaluated in the quantum-mechanical [[interaction picture]] with the Hamiltonian <math>\hat{H}_0.</math> -->
As a consequence of the principle of [[Causality (physics)|causality]] the complex-valued function <math>\tilde{\chi }(\omega )</math> has poles only in the lower half-plane. This leads to the [[Kramers‚ÄìKronig relations]], which relates the real and the imaginary parts of <math>\tilde{\chi }(\omega )</math> by integration. The simplest example is once more the [[damped harmonic oscillator]].<ref>De Clozeaux,''Linear Response Theory'', in: E. Antonƒçik et al., ''Theory of condensed matter'', IAEA Vienna, 1968</ref>
==See also== *[[Convolution]] *[[Green‚ÄìKubo relations]] *[[Fluctuation theorem]] *[[Dispersion (optics)]] *[[Lindblad equation]] *[[Semilinear response]] *[[Green's function]] *[[impulse response]] *[[Resolvent formalism]] *[[Propagator]]
==References== <references/>

{{Expert needed|Law|talk=|reason=|date=}} The '''Mar√≠a Clara doctrine''', also known as the '''Woman's Honor doctrine''', is a [[legal doctrine]] applied by Philippine courts regarding cases that concerns [[Discrimination against women|abuse against women]].
==Etymology== The doctrine was named after [[Mar√≠a Clara]] from [[Jos√© Rizal]]'s novel ''[[Noli Me T√°ngere (novel)|Noli Me T√°ngere]]''. Clara is characterized as reserved and shy and was later considered an "ideal" role model for women in Philippine culture.<ref name="notabandoned">{{cite news|last1=Patag|first1=Kristine Joy|title='SC has not abandoned ruling on Maria Clara doctrine'|url=http://old.philstar.com/headlines/2018/02/21/1789994/sc-has-not-abandoned-ruling-maria-clara-doctrine|accessdate=22 February 2018|work=The Philippine Star|date=21 February 2018}}</ref>
==Legal history== The doctrine became a part of the [[Supreme Court of the Philippines]]' [[jurisprudence]] sometime in 1960 following the ''People v. Ta√±o'' case. The high court through Justice Alejo Labrador has asserted a "well known fact" that women, especially Filipinos "would not admit that they have been abused unless that abuse had actually happened."<ref name="notabandoned"/> The court said that women's natural instict is to protect their honor.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Cawilan|first1=Christopher Lloyd|title=SC acquits 2 men of rape charges|agency=Philippine News Agency|url=http://www.pna.gov.ph/articles/1025868|accessdate=22 February 2018}}</ref>The case involved three armed robbers who the court found liable for [[gang rape|taking turns in raping]] a woman.<ref name="bm">{{cite news|last1=San Juan|first1=Joel|title=SC sets aside ‚Äòwoman‚Äôs honor‚Äô doctrine in resolving rape cases|url=https://businessmirror.com.ph/sc-sets-aside-womans-honor-doctrine-in-resolving-rape-cases/|accessdate=22 February 2018|work=Business Mirror|date=20 February 2018}}</ref>
About 58 years later since the doctrine entered the high court's jurisprudence, the Third Division of the Supreme Court reverse a ruling on January 17, 2018 by a Davao court on two people convicted of rape.<ref name="notabandoned"/> The 2018 decision was released in late-February.<ref name="ms">{{cite news|last1=Requejo|first1=Rey|title=High court drops 1960 doctrine in rape case|url=http://manilastandard.net/news/top-stories/259208/high-court-drops-1960-doctrine-in-rape-case.html|accessdate=22 February 2018|work=Manila Standard|date=21 February 2017}}</ref> The case involves an alleged rape that happened in 2009 and the two accused were sentenced of ''[[reclusi√≥n perpetua]]'', or forty years of imprisonment, in 2012. The decision was affirmed by the Court of Appeals in 2016. <ref>{{cite news|last1=Panaligan|first1=Rey|title=High Court abandons ‚Äòwoman‚Äôs honor‚Äô doctrine in rape cases|url=https://news.mb.com.ph/2018/02/20/high-court-abandons-womans-honor-doctrine-in-rape-cases/|accessdate=22 February 2018|work=Manila Bulletin|date=20 February 2018}}</ref>
The court described the doctrine as causing a "travesty of justice" by putting the accused at an "unfair disadvantage"<ref name="notabandoned"/>, criticizing the doctrine for assuming that no Filipina woman of "decent repute" would falsely claim that she was abused. It urged for the acceptance of the "realities of a woman‚Äôs dynamic role" in Philippine society today so one can "evaluate the testimony of a private complainant of rape without [[gender bias]] or cultural misconception". It also stated that the discrepancies in the alleged victim's testimonies had cast doubt on whether the rape incident did or did not happen.<ref name="bm"/>
This has led to concerns and speculations that the high court has abandoned the doctrine.<ref name="notabandoned"/> The [[Gabriela Women's Party]] condemned the decision which it viewed made the Maria Clara doctrine invalid saying the ruling reversal will empower rapists and disagreed with the court's assessment of the societal status of women.<ref name="ms"/>
On February 21, 2018, Supreme Court's spokesperson, Theodore Te has clarified that it was not the case since the high court can abandon a doctrine only during a full session.<ref name="notabandoned"/>

{{Other uses}} {{More citations needed | date = January 2017}} {{Tone|date=February 2017}} [[File:Phrenology1.jpg|thumb|200px|A [[phrenology|phrenological]] [[Brain mapping|mapping]]<ref>Oliver Elbs, ''Neuro-Esthetics: Mapological foundations and applications (Map 2003)'', (Munich 2005)</ref> of the brain. Phrenology was among the first attempts to correlate mental functions with specific parts of the brain.]] [[File:Descartes mind and body.gif|thumb|200px|right|[[Ren√© Descartes]]' illustration of [[mind/body dualism]].
Descartes believed inputs are passed on by the sensory organs to the [[Pineal gland|epiphysis]] in the brain and from there to the immaterial spirit.<ref name="Descartes1641">Descartes, R. (1641) ''Meditations on First Philosophy'', in ''The Philosophical Writings of Ren√© Descartes'', trans. by J. Cottingham, R. Stoothoff and D. Murdoch, Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1984, vol. 2, pp. 1‚Äì62.</ref>]]
The '''mind''' is a set of [[cognition|cognitive]] faculties including [[consciousness]], [[perception]], [[thought|thinking]], [[judgement]], [[language]] and [[memory]]. It is usually defined as the faculty of an entity's thoughts and consciousness.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://en.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/mind|title=mind ‚Äì definition of mind in English {{!}} Oxford Dictionaries|website=Oxford Dictionaries {{!}} English|access-date=2017-05-08}}</ref> It holds the power of imagination, recognition, and appreciation, and is responsible for processing feelings and emotions, resulting in attitudes and actions.{{Citation needed|date=December 2016}}
There is a lengthy tradition in [[philosophy of mind|philosophy]], [[religion]], [[psychology]], and [[cognitive science]] about what constitutes a mind and what are its distinguishing properties.
One open question regarding the nature of the mind is the [[mind‚Äìbody problem]], which investigates the relation of the mind to the physical [[brain]] and nervous system.<ref name=":0" /> Older viewpoints included [[Dualism (philosophy of mind)|dualism]] and [[idealism]], which considered the mind somehow non-physical.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title=Mindware|last=Clark|first=Andy|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=2014|isbn=978-0-19-982815-9|location=198 Madison Avenue, New York, 10016|pages=14, 254‚Äì256|quote=|via=}}</ref> Modern views often center around [[physicalism]] and [[Functionalism (philosophy of mind)|functionalism]], which hold that the mind is roughly identical with the brain or [[Reductionism|reducible]] to physical phenomena such as [[neuron|neuronal activity]]<ref>Smart, J.J.C., "The Mind/Brain Identity Theory", The Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy (Fall 2011 Edition), Edward N. Zalta (ed.), [http://plato.stanford.edu/archives/fall2011/entries/mind-identity/]</ref>{{Request quotation|date=December 2016}}, though dualism and idealism continue to have many supporters. Another question concerns which types of [[being]]s are capable of having minds (New Scientist 8 September 2018 p10).{{Citation needed|date=December 2016}} For example, whether mind is exclusive to humans, possessed also by some or all [[animals]], by all [[life|living things]], whether it is a strictly definable characteristic at all, or whether mind can also be a property of some types of [[artificial intelligence|human-made machines]].{{Citation needed|date=December 2016}}
Whatever its nature, it is generally agreed that mind is that which enables a being to have [[subjectivity|subjective]] [[awareness]] and [[intentionality]] towards their environment, to [[perceive]] and respond to [[Stimulus (psychology)|stimuli]] with some kind of [[Agency (philosophy)|agency]], and to have consciousness, including thinking and [[feeling]].{{Citation needed|date=January 2017}}
The concept of mind is understood in many different ways by many different cultural and religious traditions. Some see mind as a property exclusive to humans whereas others ascribe properties of mind to non-living entities (e.g. [[panpsychism]] and [[animism]]), to animals and to [[deity|deities]]. Some of the earliest recorded speculations linked mind (sometimes described as identical with [[soul]] or [[spirit]]) to theories concerning both [[life after death]], and [[cosmology|cosmological]] and [[Nature (philosophy)|natural]] order, for example in the doctrines of [[Zoroaster]], [[Gautama Buddha|the Buddha]], Plato, [[Aristotle]], and other ancient [[Greek philosophy|Greek]], [[Indian philosophy|Indian]] and, later, [[Islamic psychological thought|Islamic]] and medieval European philosophers.
Important philosophers of mind include [[Plato]], [[Patanjali]], [[Ren√© Descartes|Descartes]], [[Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz|Leibniz]], [[John Locke|Locke]], [[George Berkeley|Berkeley]], [[David Hume|Hume]], [[Kant]], [[Hegel]], [[Schopenhauer]], [[John Searle|Searle]], [[Daniel Dennett|Dennett]], [[Jerry Fodor|Fodor]], [[Thomas Nagel|Nagel]], and [[David Chalmers|Chalmers]].<ref>{{Cite web | url=http://leiterreports.typepad.com/blog/2016/01/20-most-important-philosophers-of-mind-since-wwii.html | title=20 "Most Important" Philosophers of Mind since WWII}}</ref> Psychologists such as [[Sigmund Freud|Freud]] and [[William James|James]], and [[computer science|computer scientists]] such as [[Alan Turing|Turing]] and [[Hilary Putnam|Putnam]] developed influential theories about the nature of the mind. The possibility of nonbiological minds is explored in the field of [[artificial intelligence]], which works closely in relation with [[cybernetics]] and [[information theory]] to understand the ways in which information processing by nonbiological machines is comparable or different to mental phenomena in the human mind.{{Citation needed|date=December 2016}}
The mind is also portrayed as the [[Stream of consciousness (psychology)|stream of consciousness]] where sense impressions and mental phenomena are constantly changing<ref name=Karunamuni2017>{{cite journal |author= Karunamuni N, Weerasekera R. |title= Theoretical Foundations to Guide Mindfulness Meditation: A Path to Wisdom |journal= Current Psychology |date=Jun 2017 | doi= 10.1007/s12144-017-9631-7|url= http://mindrxiv.org/mfs63/ |type= Submitted manuscript }}</ref><ref name=Aggregates>{{cite journal|author= Karunamuni N.D.|title=The Five-Aggregate Model of the Mind|journal=SAGE Open|volume=5 |issue=2 |pages=215824401558386|date=May 2015 | url= http://sgo.sagepub.com/content/spsgo/5/2/2158244015583860.full.pdf | doi=10.1177/2158244015583860}}</ref>
==Etymology== The original meaning of [[Old English]] ''[[:wikt:gemynd|gemynd]]'' was the faculty of [[memory]], not of thought in general.{{Citation needed|date=January 2017}} Hence ''call to mind'', ''come to mind'', ''keep in mind'', ''to have mind of'', etc. The word retains this sense in Scotland.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://en.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/mind|title=mind ‚Äì definition of mind in English {{!}} Oxford Dictionaries|website=Oxford Dictionaries {{!}} English|access-date=2017-08-19}}</ref> [[Old English]] had other words to express "mind", such as ''[[:wikt:hyge|hyge]]'' "mind, spirit".{{Citation needed|date=January 2017}}
The meaning of "memory" is shared with [[Old Norse]], which has ''[[Muninn|munr]]''. The word is originally from a [[PIE]] verbal root ''{{PIE|*men-}}'', meaning "to think, remember", whence also Latin'' [[:wikt:mens#Latin|mens]]'' "mind", Sanskrit ''[[:wikt:‡§Æ‡§®‡§∏‡•ç|{{IAST|manas}}]]'' "mind" and Greek [[:wikt:ŒºŒ≠ŒΩŒøœÇ|ŒºŒ≠ŒΩŒøœÇ]] "mind, courage, anger".
The generalization of ''mind'' to include all mental faculties, thought, [[Volition (psychology)|volition]], feeling and memory, gradually develops over the 14th and 15th centuries.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.etymonline.com/index.php?term=mind|title=Online Etymology Dictionary|website=www.etymonline.com|access-date=2017-01-02}}</ref>
==Definitions== The attributes that make up the mind are debated. Some psychologists argue that only the "higher" intellectual functions constitute mind, particularly reason and [[memory]].<ref>{{cite book|last1=Ba≈üar|first1=Erol|title=Brain body mind oscillations in scope of uncertainty principle|date=2010|publisher=Springer|location=New York|isbn=978-1441961365|page=5|url=https://books.google.com/?id=NAbMHo-ux58C&pg=PA5&lpg=PA5&dq=Some+psychologists+argue+that+only+the+%22higher%22+intellectual+functions+constitute+mind,+particularly+reason+and+memory#v=onepage&q=Some%20psychologists%20argue%20that%20only%20the%20%22higher%22%20intellectual%20functions%20constitute%20mind%2C%20particularly%20reason%20and%20memory&f=false}}</ref> In this view the emotions ‚Äî [[love]], [[hate]], [[fear]], and [[joy]] ‚Äî are more ''primitive ''or subjective in nature and should be seen as different from the mind as such. Others argue that various rational and emotional states cannot be so separated, that they are of the same nature and origin, and should therefore be considered all part of it as mind.{{citation needed|date=April 2015}}
In popular usage, ''mind ''is frequently synonymous with ''thought'': the private conversation with ourselves that we carry on "inside our heads."<ref>{{cite book|last1=Israel|first1=Richard|last2=North|first2=Vanda|title=Mind Chi Re-wire Your Brain in 8 Minutes a Day ; Strategies for Success in Business and Life|date=2010|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|location=Chichester|isbn=978-1907321375|page=12|url=https://books.google.com/?id=VCP63CWtVqIC&pg=PA12&dq=mind+is+frequently+synonymous+with+thought:#v=onepage&q=mind%20is%20frequently%20synonymous%20with%20thought%3A&f=false|accessdate=18 April 2015}}</ref> Thus we "make up our minds," "change our minds" or are "of two minds" about something. One of the key attributes of the mind in this sense is that it is a private sphere to which no one but the owner has access. No one else can "know our mind." They can only interpret what we consciously or unconsciously communicate.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Masters|first1=Frances|title=Harness your Amazingly Creative Mind|url=http://www.thefusionmodel.com/harness-amazingly-creative-mind/|website=www.thefusionmodel.com|accessdate=18 April 2015|date=2014-08-29}}</ref>
==Mental faculties== {{See also|Nous|Reason|Modularity of mind|Mental process}}
Broadly speaking, mental faculties are the various functions of the mind, or things the mind can "do".
[[Thought]] is a mental act that allows humans to make sense of things in the world, and to represent and interpret them in ways that are significant, or which accord with their needs, attachments, goals, commitments, plans, ends, desires, etc. Thinking involves the [[symbol]]ic or [[semiotic]] mediation of [[idea]]s or data, as when we form [[concept]]s, engage in [[problem solving]], reasoning, and making [[choice|decisions]]. Words that refer to similar concepts and processes include [[deliberation]], [[cognition]], [[idea]]tion, [[discourse]] and [[imagination]].
Thinking is sometimes described as a "higher" [[cognitive]] function and the analysis of thinking processes is a part of [[cognitive psychology]]. It is also deeply connected with our capacity to make and use [[tools]]; to understand [[causality|cause and effect]]; to recognize patterns of significance; to comprehend and [[world disclosure|disclose]] unique contexts of experience or activity; and to respond to the world in a meaningful way.
[[Memory]] is the ability to preserve, retain, and subsequently recall, knowledge, information or experience. Although memory has traditionally been a persistent theme in [[philosophy]], the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries also saw the study of memory emerge as a subject of inquiry within the paradigms of [[cognitive psychology]]. In recent decades, it has become one of the pillars of a new branch of science called [[cognitive neuroscience]], a marriage between cognitive psychology and [[neuroscience]].
[[Imagination]] is the activity of generating or evoking novel situations, [[image]]s, ideas or other [[qualia]] in the mind. It is a characteristically [[Subjectivity|subjective]] ''activity'', rather than a direct or passive experience. The term is technically used in [[psychology]] for the process of reviving in the mind [[perception|percepts]] of objects formerly given in sense perception. Since this use of the term conflicts with that of ordinary [[language]], some psychologists have preferred to describe this process as "[[wikt:Imaging|imaging]]" or "[[wikt:Imagery|imagery]]" or to speak of it as "reproductive" as opposed to "productive" or "constructive" imagination. Things imagined are said to be seen in the "[[mind's eye]]". Among the many practical functions of imagination are the ability to project possible futures (or histories), to "see" things from another's perspective, and to change the way something is perceived, including to make decisions to respond to, or enact, what is imagined.
[[Consciousness]] in mammals (this includes humans) is an aspect of the mind generally thought to comprise qualities such as [[subjectivity]], [[sentience]], and the ability to [[perception|perceive]] the relationship between [[Personal identity|oneself]] and one's [[environment (biophysical)|environment]]. It is a subject of much research in [[philosophy of mind]], [[psychology]], [[neuroscience]], and [[cognitive science]]. Some philosophers divide consciousness into [[phenomena]]l consciousness, which is subjective experience itself, and access consciousness, which refers to the global availability of information to processing systems in the brain.<ref name="Bl">Ned Block: "On a Confusion about a Function of Consciousness" in: ''The Behavioral and Brain Sciences'', 1995.</ref> Phenomenal consciousness has many different experienced qualities, often referred to as [[qualia]]. Phenomenal consciousness is usually consciousness ''of'' something or ''about'' something, a property known as [[intentionality]] in philosophy of mind.
==Mental content== Mental contents are those items that are thought of as being "in" the mind, and capable of being formed and manipulated by mental processes and faculties. Examples include [[thought]]s, [[concept]]s, [[memories]], [[emotion]]s, [[percept]]s and [[intention]]s. Philosophical theories of mental content include [[internalism]], [[externalism]], [[direct and indirect realism|representationalism]] and [[intentionality]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/content-narrow/ | title=Narrow Mental Content | publisher=Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy | accessdate=7 September 2015}}</ref>
===Memetics=== [[Memetics]] is a theory of mental content based on an analogy with [[Darwinian evolution]], which was originated by [[Richard Dawkins]] and [[Douglas Hofstadter]] in the 1980s. It is an [[evolutionary model]] of cultural [[information transfer]]. A [[meme]], analogous to a [[gene]], is an idea, belief, pattern of behaviour (etc.) "hosted" in one or more individual minds, and can reproduce itself from mind to mind. Thus what would otherwise be regarded as one individual influencing another to adopt a belief, is seen memetically as a meme reproducing itself.
==Relation to the brain== {{See also|Cognitive neuroscience}}
In animals, the [[brain]], or ''encephalon'' ([[Greek (language)|Greek]] for "in the head"), is the control center of the [[central nervous system]], responsible for [[thought]]. In most animals, the brain is located in the head, protected by the [[skull]] and close to the primary sensory apparatus of [[Visual perception|vision]], [[Hearing (sense)|hearing]], [[equilibrioception]], [[taste]] and [[olfaction]]. While all [[vertebrate]]s have a brain, most [[invertebrate]]s have either a centralized brain or collections of individual [[ganglion|ganglia]]. Primitive animals such as [[sponge]]s do not have a brain at all. Brains can be extremely complex. For example, the [[human brain]] contains around 86 billion [[neuron]]s, each linked to as many as 10,000 others.<ref>{{cite book|last=Whishaw|first=Bryan Kolb, Ian Q.|title=An Introduction to Brain and Behavior|year=2010|publisher=Worth Publishers|location=New York|isbn=978-0-7167-7691-8|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zIBEEP2b1MIC|edition=3rd |accessdate=11 May 2012|page=72}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Sherwood|first=Lauralee|title=Fundamentals of Human Physiology|year=2011|publisher=Brooks/Cole Cengage Learning|location=Belmont, CA|isbn=978-0-8400-6225-3|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jl4rLDuewo4C|edition=4th |accessdate=11 May 2012|page=91}}</ref>
Understanding the relationship between the brain and the mind ‚Äì [[mind‚Äìbody problem]] is one of the central issues in the history of [[philosophy]] ‚Äì is a challenging problem both philosophically and scientifically.<ref>Patricia Smith Churchland, [https://books.google.com/books?id=hAeFMFW3rDUC ''Neurophilosophy: toward a unified science of the mind-brain''], MIT Press, 1989</ref> There are three major philosophical schools of thought concerning the answer: dualism, materialism, and idealism. [[Dualism (philosophy of mind)|Dualism]] holds that the mind exists independently of the brain;<ref>Hart, W.D. (1997): [https://books.google.com/books?id=GFtVBGAn5-YC&pg=PA265&dq=dualism+%22The+mind-body+problem+is+the+question+how+the+mind+is+attached+to+the+body%22&hl=en&ei=VKuFTtvlNYSN4gTVrf20Dw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCwQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=dualism%20%22The%20mind-body%20problem%20is%20the%20question%20how%20the%20mind%20is%20attached%20to%20the%20body%22&f=false ‚ÄòDualism‚Äô, pp. 265‚Äì267] in S. Guttenplan (ed.), [https://books.google.com/books?id=GFtVBGAn5-YC ''A Companion to the Philosophy of Mind''], Blackwell</ref> [[materialism]] holds that mental phenomena are identical to neuronal phenomena;<ref name="DicPhil">A.R. Lacey, ''A Dictionary of Philosophy'', 1996</ref> and [[idealism (philosophy)|idealism]] holds that only mental phenomena exist.<ref name="DicPhil"/>
Through most of history many philosophers found it inconceivable that cognition could be implemented by a physical substance such as brain tissue (that is neurons and synapses).<ref>[[#refChurchland|''Neurophilosophy'']], Ch. 6</ref> [[Descartes]], who thought extensively about mind-brain relationships, found it possible to explain reflexes and other simple behaviors in [[The Description of the Human Body|mechanistic terms]], although he did not believe that complex thought, and language in particular, could be explained by reference to the physical brain alone.<ref>[[#refDescartes|Descartes, ''Description of the human body'']]</ref>
The most straightforward scientific evidence of a strong relationship between the physical brain [[matter]] and the mind is the impact physical alterations to the brain have on the mind, such as with [[traumatic brain injury]] and [[psychoactive drug]] use.<ref>[[#refBoake|Boake and Diller, 2005]]</ref> Philosopher [[Patricia Churchland]] notes that this drug-mind interaction indicates an intimate connection between the brain and the mind.<ref>[[#refChurchland|''Neurophilosophy'']], Ch. 8</ref>
In addition to the philosophical questions, the relationship between mind and brain involves a number of scientific questions, including understanding the relationship between mental activity and brain activity, the exact mechanisms by which drugs influence [[cognition]], and the [[neural correlates of consciousness]].
Theoretical approaches to explain how mind emerges from the brain include [[connectionism]], [[computationalism]] and [[Bayesian brain]].
==Evolutionary history of the human mind== The [[evolution of human intelligence]] refers to several theories that aim to describe how human [[intelligence]] has [[evolution|evolved]] in relation to the evolution of the [[human brain]] and the [[origin of language]].<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Harnad, S.R., Steklis, H.D., & Lancaster, J.E.|title=Origins and evolution of language and speech|journal=Annals of the New York Academy of Sciences|volume=280|issue=1|pages=1‚Äì2|date=1976|doi=10.1111/j.1749-6632.1976.tb25462.x|bibcode=1976NYASA.280....1H}}</ref>
The timeline of [[human evolution]] spans some 7 million years, from the separation of the genus ''[[Chimpanzee|Pan]]'' until the emergence of [[behavioral modernity]] by 50,000 years ago. Of this timeline, the first 3 million years concern ''[[Sahelanthropus tchadensis|Sahelanthropus]]'', the following 2 million concern ''[[Australopithecus]]'', while the final 2 million span the history of actual ''[[Homo (genus)|Homo]]'' species (the [[Paleolithic]]).
Many traits of human intelligence, such as [[empathy]], [[theory of mind]], [[mourning]], [[ritual]], and the use of [[Great ape language|symbols]] and [[tool]]s, are already apparent in [[great ape]]s although in lesser sophistication than in humans.
There is a debate between supporters of the idea of a sudden emergence of intelligence, or "[[Behavioural modernity#Great leap forward|Great leap forward]]" and those of a gradual or [[Behavioural modernity#Continuum hypothesis|continuum hypothesis]].
Theories of the evolution of intelligence include: * [[Robin Dunbar]]'s social brain hypothesis<ref name="The Social Brain Hypothesis">[http://www.liv.ac.uk/evolpsyc/Evol_Anthrop_6.pdfThe Social Brain Hypothesis] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150713121559/http://www.liv.ac.uk/evolpsyc/Evol_Anthrop_6.pdfThe |date=2015-07-13 }}</ref> * [[Geoffrey Miller (psychologist)|Geoffrey Miller]]'s [[sexual selection]] hypothesis concerning [[Sexual selection in human evolution]]<ref>{{cite book|last=Miller|authorlink=Geoffrey Miller (psychologist)|title=The Mating Mind|isbn=978-0-8058-5749-8|year=2008}}</ref> * The ecological dominance-social competition (EDSC)<ref name=flinn>{{cite web| url=http://web.missouri.edu/~gearyd/Flinnetal2005.pdf|title=Flinn, M.V., Geary, D.C., & Ward, C.V. (2005). Ecological dominance, social competition, and coalitionary arms races: Why humans evolved extraordinary intelligence| accessdate=2007-05-05}}</ref> explained by Mark V. Flinn, David C. Geary and Carol V. Ward based mainly on work by [[Richard D. Alexander]]. * The idea of intelligence as a signal of good health and resistance to disease. * The [[Group selection]] theory contends that organism characteristics that provide benefits to a group (clan, tribe, or larger population) can evolve despite individual disadvantages such as those cited above. * The idea that intelligence is connected with nutrition, and thereby with status.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0306987704000416 |title= Enhanced nutrition of offspring as a crucial factor for the evolution of intelligence on land |website= |publisher= |accessdate= }}</ref> A higher IQ could be a signal that an individual comes from and lives in a physical and social environment where nutrition levels are high, and vice versa.
==Philosophy of mind== {{Main|Philosophy of mind}}
Philosophy of mind is the branch of [[philosophy]] that studies the nature of the mind, [[mental event]]s, [[mental function]]s, [[mental property|mental properties]], [[consciousness]] and their relationship to the physical body. The ''[[mind‚Äìbody problem]]'', i.e. the relationship of the mind to the body, is commonly seen as the central issue in philosophy of mind, although there are other issues concerning the nature of the mind that do not involve its relation to the physical body.<ref name="Kim1">{{cite book | last = Kim | first = J. | editor = Honderich, Ted | title = Problems in the Philosophy of Mind. Oxford Companion to Philosophy | year = 1995 | publisher = [[Oxford University Press]] | location = Oxford | id = | doi = }} <!--Kim, J., "Problems in the Philosophy of Mind". ''Oxford Companion to Philosophy''. Ted Honderich (ed.) Oxford:Oxford University Press. 1998.--></ref> [[Jos√© Manuel Rodriguez Delgado]] writes, "In present popular usage, soul and mind are not clearly differentiated and some people, more or less consciously, still feel that the soul, and perhaps the mind, may enter or leave the body as independent entities."<ref>{{cite book | author=James M.R. Delgado | title= Physical control of the mind; towards a psycho civilized society | page=25 | year=1969 | publisher=Fitzhenry & Whiteside Limited | location=Toronto}}</ref>
''[[Dualism (philosophy of mind)|Dualism]]'' and ''[[monism]]'' are the two major schools of thought that attempt to resolve the mind‚Äìbody problem. Dualism is the position that mind and body are in some way separate from each other. It can be traced back to [[Plato]],<ref name="Plato">{{cite book | author = Plato |editor1=E.A. Duke |editor2=W.F. Hicken |editor3=W.S.M. Nicoll |editor4=D.B. Robinson |editor5=J.C.G. Strachan | title = Phaedo | edition = | year = 1995 | publisher = Clarendon Press | location = | id = }}<!--{{cite book | author=Plato | title=Phaedo}} ed. E.A. Duke, W.F. Hicken, W.S.M. Nicoll, D.B. Robinson and J.C.G. Strachan, Oxford: Clarendon Press, 1995.--></ref> [[Aristotle]]<ref name="Rob">Robinson, H. (1983): ‚ÄòAristotelian dualism‚Äô, Oxford Studies in Ancient Philosophy 1, 123‚Äì44.</ref><ref>Nussbaum, M.C. (1984): ‚ÄòAristotelian dualism‚Äô, Oxford Studies in Ancient Philosophy, 2, 197‚Äì207.</ref><ref>Nussbaum, M.C. and Rorty, A.O. (1992): Essays on Aristotle's De Anima, Clarendon Press, Oxford.</ref> and the [[Nyaya]], [[Samkhya]] and [[Yoga]] schools of [[Hinduism|Hindu]] philosophy,<ref name="Sa">{{cite web|url=http://www.experiencefestival.com/a/Sankhya/id/23117 |title=Sankhya:Hindu philosophy: The Sankhya |author=Sri Swami Sivananda |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060515215340/http://www.experiencefestival.com/a/Sankhya/id/23117 |archivedate=2006-05-15 |df= }}</ref> but it was most precisely formulated by [[Ren√© Descartes]] in the 17th century.<ref name="De">{{cite book | author=Descartes, Ren√© | title=Discourse on Method and Meditations on First Philosophy | publisher=Hacket Publishing Company | isbn=978-0-87220-421-8 | year=1998 }}</ref> ''[[Dualism (philosophy of mind)|Substance dualists]]'' argue that the mind is an independently existing substance, whereas ''[[Property dualism|Property dualists]]'' maintain that the mind is a group of independent properties that [[emergentism|emerge]] from and cannot be reduced to the brain, but that it is not a distinct substance.<ref name="Du">Hart, W.D. (1996) "Dualism", in Samuel Guttenplan (org) ''A Companion to the Philosophy of Mind'', Blackwell, Oxford, 265‚Äì267.</ref>
The 20th century philosopher Martin Heidegger suggested that subjective experience and activity (i.e. the "mind") cannot be made sense of in terms of [[Descartes|Cartesian]] "substances" that bear "properties" at all (whether the mind itself is thought of as a distinct, separate kind of substance or not). This is because the nature of subjective, ''qualitative'' experience is incoherent in terms of ‚Äì or semantically [[Commensurability (philosophy of science)|incommensurable]] with the concept of ‚Äì substances that bear properties. This is a fundamentally [[ontology|ontological]] argument.<ref>Hubert Dreyfus, "Critique of Descartes I" (recorded lecture), University of California at Berkeley, September 18, 2007.</ref>
The philosopher of [[cognitive science]] [[Daniel Dennett]], for example, argues there is no such thing as a narrative center called the "mind", but that instead there is simply a collection of sensory inputs and outputs: different kinds of "software" running in parallel.<ref name=Dennett1991>{{cite book |author=Dennett, Daniel |title=Consciousness Explained |year=1991 |publisher=Little Brown |location=Boston, Massachusetts |isbn=978-0-316-18065-8|title-link=Consciousness Explained }}</ref><!--find page # or page range for this citation--> Psychologist [[B.F. Skinner]] argued that the mind is an explanatory fiction that diverts attention from environmental causes of behavior;<ref>Skinner, B.F. About Behaviorism 1974, pp. 74‚Äì75</ref> he considered the mind a "black box" and thought that mental processes may be better conceived of as forms of covert verbal behavior.<ref>Skinner, B.F. ''About Behaviorism'', Chapter 7: Thinking</ref><ref>A thesis against which [[Noam Chomsky#Contributions to psychology|Noam Chomsky]] advanced a considerable polemic.</ref>
Philosopher [[David Chalmers]] has argued that the third person approach to uncovering mind and consciousness is not effective, such as looking into other's brains or observing human conduct, but that a first person approach is necessary. Such a first person perspective indicates that the mind must be conceptualized as something distinct from the brain.
The mind has also been described as manifesting from moment to moment, one thought moment at a time as a fast flowing stream, where sense impressions and mental phenomena are constantly changing.<ref name="Aggregates"/><ref name="Karunamuni2017"/>
===Mind/body perspectives=== ''Monism'' is the position that mind and body are not [[physiology|physiologically]] and ontologically distinct kinds of entities. This view was first advocated in [[Western Philosophy]] by [[Parmenides]] in the 5th Century BC and was later espoused by the 17th Century [[Rationalism|rationalist]] [[Baruch Spinoza]].<ref name="Spin">Spinoza, Baruch (1670) ''Tractatus Theologico-Politicus'' (A Theologico-Political Treatise).</ref> According to Spinoza's [[dual-aspect theory]], mind and body are two aspects of an underlying reality which he variously described as "Nature" or "God". * ''[[Physicalism|Physicalists]]'' argue that only the entities postulated by physical theory exist, and that the mind will eventually be explained in terms of these entities as physical theory continues to evolve. * ''[[idealism (philosophy)|Idealists]]'' maintain that the mind is all that exists and that the external world is either mental itself, or an illusion created by the mind. * ''[[neutral monism|Neutral monists]]'' adhere to the position that perceived things in the world can be regarded as either physical or mental depending on whether one is interested in their relationship to other things in the world or their relationship to the perceiver. For example, a red spot on a wall is physical in its dependence on the wall and the pigment of which it is made, but it is mental in so far as its perceived redness depends on the workings of the visual system. Unlike dual-aspect theory, neutral monism does not posit a more fundamental substance of which mind and body are aspects.
The most common monisms in the 20th and 21st centuries have all been variations of physicalism; these positions include [[behaviorism]], the [[type physicalism|type identity theory]], [[anomalous monism]] and [[functionalism (philosophy of mind)|functionalism]].<ref name="Kim">Kim, J., "Mind-Body Problem", ''Oxford Companion to Philosophy''. Ted Honderich (ed.). Oxford:Oxford University Press. 1995.</ref>
Many modern philosophers of mind adopt either a ''reductive'' or ''non-reductive physicalist'' position, maintaining in their different ways that the mind is not something separate from the body.<ref name="Kim" /> These approaches have been particularly influential in the sciences, e.g. in the fields of [[sociobiology]], [[computer science]], [[evolutionary psychology]] and the various [[neuroscience]]s.<ref name="PsyBio">Pinel, J. ''Psychobiology'', (1990) Prentice Hall, Inc. {{ISBN|88-15-07174-1}}</ref><ref name="LeDoux">LeDoux, J. (2002) ''The Synaptic Self: How Our Brains Become Who We Are'', New York: Viking Penguin. {{ISBN|88-7078-795-8}}</ref><ref name="RussNor">{{Russell Norvig 2003}}</ref><ref name="DawkRich">Dawkins, R. ''The Selfish Gene'' (1976) Oxford:Oxford University Press.</ref><!----Well, you get f** idea. There are billions of refs for this---> Other philosophers, however, adopt a non-physicalist position which challenges the notion that the mind is a purely physical construct.<!--eg, Chalmers ref and whatever else you like----> * ''Reductive physicalists'' assert that all mental states and properties will eventually be explained by scientific accounts of physiological processes and states.<ref name="Pat">{{cite book | author=Churchland, Patricia | title=Neurophilosophy: Toward a Unified Science of the Mind-Brain | publisher=MIT Press | year=1986 | isbn=978-0-262-03116-5 }}</ref><ref name="Paul">{{cite journal | author=Churchland, Paul | title=Eliminative Materialism and the Propositional Attitudes | journal=[[Journal of Philosophy]] | year=1981 | pages=67‚Äì90 | volume = 78 | doi = 10.2307/2025900 | issue=2 | jstor=2025900}}</ref><ref name="Smart">{{cite journal | author=Smart, J.J.C. | title=Sensations and Brain Processes | journal=Philosophical Review | year=1956}}</ref> * ''Non-reductive physicalists'' argue that although the brain is all there ''is'' to the mind, the predicates and vocabulary used in mental descriptions and explanations are indispensable, and cannot be reduced to the language and lower-level explanations of physical science.<ref name="Davidson">{{cite book | author=Donald Davidson | title=Essays on Actions and Events | publisher=Oxford University Press | year=1980 | isbn=978-0-19-924627-4 }}</ref><ref name="Pu">Putnam, Hilary (1967). "Psychological Predicates", in W.H. Capitan and D.D. Merrill, eds., ''Art, Mind and Religion'' Pittsburgh: [[University of Pittsburgh Press]].</ref>
Continued progress in [[neuroscience]] has helped to clarify many of these issues, and its findings have been taken by many to support [[Physicalism|physicalists]]' assertions.<ref name="Murphy">{{cite journal|last=Farah|first=Martha J.|author2=Murphy, Nancey|title=Neuroscience and the Soul|journal=Science|date=February 2009|volume=323|issue=5918|page=1168|doi=10.1126/science.323.5918.1168a|pmid=19251609|url=http://www.sciencemag.org/content/323/5918/1168.1.full|accessdate=20 November 2012}}</ref><ref name="Koch">{{cite journal|last=Koch|first=Christof|title=Do Not Underestimate Science|journal=Science|date=July 2009|volume=325|issue=5939|page=392|doi=10.1126/science.325_392b|pmid=19628839|url=http://www.sciencemag.org/content/325/5939/392.2.full|accessdate=14 November 2012|bibcode=2009Sci...325..392K}}</ref> Nevertheless, our knowledge is incomplete, and modern philosophers of mind continue to discuss how subjective [[qualia]] and the [[intentional stance|intentional]] mental states can be [[naturalism (philosophy)|naturally]] explained.<ref name="Int">{{cite book | author=Dennett, Daniel | title=The intentional stance | publisher=MIT Press | location=Cambridge, Mass. |year=1998 |isbn=978-0-262-54053-7 }}</ref><ref name="Searleint">{{cite book | author=Searle, John | title=Intentionality. A Paper on the Philosophy of Mind | publisher=Nachdr. ==Scientific study== [[Image:Architecture of Spaun.jpeg|thumb|300px|Simplified diagram of ''Spaun'', a 2.5-million-neuron computational model of the brain. '''(A)''' The corresponding physical regions and connections of the human brain. '''(B)''' The mental architecture of Spaun.<ref name="Spaun">{{cite journal|last=Eliasmith|first=Chris|author2=Terrence C.
